channel.title: BBC News - Business
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Gas crisis: Two energy firms go bust amid warning more to come
item.description: Avro and Green collapse, with hundreds of thousands of customers facing higher bills with new suppliers.

item.title: Food firms warn of panic-buying this Christmas
item.description: Empty supermarket shelves may become commonplace as labour shortages bite, industry bodies say.

item.title: Travel rule change delayed by lateral flow test shortage
item.description: Transport Secretary Grant Shapps says private Covid testing firms cannot supply enough lateral flow tests.

item.title: Gas price crisis: Food firms face huge price rise for carbon dioxide
item.description: The US supplier of CO2, which will receive millions in UK taxpayer support to reopen, will hike prices.

item.title: US lifting ban on imports of British lamb, says Boris Johnson
item.description: The PM admits the UK is now aiming only for "incremental steps" on US trade, rather than a full agreement.

item.title: Fraudsters steal £4m a day as crime surges
item.description: Total losses through fraud rockets by 30% in the first half of the year, with many victims not refunded.

item.title: Catalogue of errors led to £1bn of state pension underpayments
item.description: The National Audit Office says 134,000 pensioners, mostly women, were affected by a preventable scandal.

item.title: Pret to hire 3,000 new staff as city workers return
item.description: The coffee and sandwich chain plans to hire 3,000 staff after cutting same number in 2020.

item.title: Pandemic has changed travel forever, says AirBnB boss
item.description: Boss Brian Chesky says people are increasingly combining business and leisure travel thanks to remote working.

item.title: Evergrande: Crisis-hit firm strikes China debt deal
item.description: The company is also due to make a $83.5m interest payment on an offshore bond on Thursday.

item.title: 'No clear end to HS2 cost and delays' say MPs
item.description: The Public Accounts Committee is "increasingly alarmed" about key parts of the rail project.

item.title: Joe Biden plays down chances of UK-US trade deal
item.description: The US president's comments come as he meets Boris Johnson for talks in the White House.

item.title: Failing energy firms may mean higher bills, warns regulator
item.description: Energy supplier Green is the latest firm to announce it is struggling to cope with the gas price crisis.

item.title: China pledges to stop building new coal energy plants abroad
item.description: The announcement is the country's latest climate pledge and a major step forward to address emissions.

item.title: Major record labels could face competition inquiry
item.description: The competition watchdog has been asked whether major record labels are distorting the market.

item.title: Mask-wearing on public transport sees big drop
item.description: Only 20% still wear masks at train stations now it is no longer compulsory, according to Network Rail.

item.title: Covid travel test change date needed to avoid losses
item.description: Airlines and airports say they need a date for when PCR tests are removed so they don't lose out on bookings.

item.title: German elections: Businesses face future without Merkel
item.description: Many companies in Germany are focused on short-term survival in the hope of medium-term revival.

item.title: How 'nerd' culture powered through the pandemic
item.description: Meet the online content creators beating the odds to build successful careers from their passions.

item.title: Can apps manage our chronic health conditions?
item.description: A Swedish tech firm has created an app to help alleviate people's joint pain.

item.title: 'Looking back, it was an amazing thing I did'
item.description: Meet the founder on a 10-year mission to disrupt Japan's rigid work culture.

item.title: Gen Z battles to bring back unions, one Starbucks at a time
item.description: Younger Americans are reviving US labour activism amid stagnant wages and Covid hardship.

item.title: Why taking up an instrument has struck a chord for so many
item.description: The pandemic led to around 1m UK adults learning an instrument and many taking music lessons.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'You can run a business and have a baby'
item.description: Planning for a maternity leave when you're the boss of a fast-growing company.

item.title: Why even giant ships can't solve the shipping crisis
item.description: A shortage of vessels is hampering global trade and may lead to empty shelves before Christmas.

item.title: Amazon's Cape Town base: The battle to save South African culture
item.description: Some indigenous groups say the planned office in Cape Town is on culturally important land.

item.title: The pressures - and rewards - of being an influencer
item.description: Running your own popular YouTube channel can be lucrative, but it comes with downsides.

item.title: The epicentre of Britain's pandemic house price boom
item.description: House prices have surged in many parts of the UK - and in one district they have risen by 29% in a year.

item.title: Could a reboot make social media a nicer place?
item.description: A Harvard University project will explore whether social media can be de-toxed

item.title: Women's state pension: 'It is like you've lived one big lie'
item.description: How women born in the 1950s had their retirement plans upended by state pension age changes.

item.title: How a monkey launched the pop-it toy craze
item.description: Why it took a TikTok primate to turn a forty-year-old idea into a global hit

item.title: The models that turned Instagram into their DIY catwalk
item.description: New York Fashion Week marks a tentative return - but how did supermodels keep working through Covid?

item.title: CEO Secrets: The bra boss busting stereotypes
item.description: Leanne Cahill, CEO of Bravissimo, shares her journey from shop floor to boardroom in retail.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.
